title: Am I the only one who thought nimbus cloud was a good rune?
body:
A lot of ppl didn't even notice, but this rune worked well with phase rush. I did get the chance to test it on the PBE. It allowed you to get a controlled move speed buff from which procing phase rush was much easier. 

PPL complained about losing ultimate hat but what a lot of ppl don't realize is that ultimate hat worked multiplicatively with CDR. At 40% CDR, ultimate hat only gave an additional 10% CDR to the ult.

Honestly, I felt nimbus cloud was way more useful for engaging and disengaging. And now its seems riot is not bringing it back.

Am I the only one who thought nimbus cloud was a good rune?

replies.body:
I was really excited for nimbus cloak (I super thought it was cloak, unless they changed it later) with Swain.

But I *do* legit feel that it fits better in the domination tree; movement speed is something pretty characteristic of assassins, so I still don't know why they put it into the sorcery tree. Those that want to combo it with phase rush could have still done so without taking ulti hat away from mages that *don't* want to go into dom.

My thought too. I thought it looked like a fantastic rune to add to the game, I just disagree with putting it in sorcery since so many of the champs that commonly go into sorcery have ults that don't synergize with such a rune (As an example, Vel'Koz gets nothing for this rune unless he ends his ult as soon as he uses it since he has to stand still to use his ult).

Honest question here, but what Mage wants Ulti Hat but do NOT want to go into Dom? From what I can tell (but admittedly I'm not a great Mage player), it's mostly Burst Mage wanting Ulti Hat, and they fit well in Dom.

They fit okay with the *theme* of domination, but there aren't many runes there that I think are very good for them.

Cheap shot is only good if you can reliably proc, taste of blood might be okay, eyeball collection is meh. Those are the only real choices, and they are simply outdone by the inspiration tree, imo. Biscuits, magical footwear, and cosmic insight are all stronger options, imo. Add that to the fact that you're forcing them to take something less optimal in the sorc tree (manaflow, most likely), and it looks weaker to me.

It might not be a huge power difference, but it's one of those changes that's going to significantly alter the way mages do runes, and thus have significant impact on their their optimal gameplay. It feels like change for the sake of change; they could just put nimbus cloak in dom tree and minimize the impact on mages.
Can't you go Domination/Inspiration?

Yes, and that might very well happen. Again, I still think it's a net negative, since the sorcery tree was supposed to be for mages. If mages are going dom/inspiration, then what is sorcery even there for? It'll just be underused.

If you go back to the old discussions before Rune Reforged release, Riot was very clear that the Paths weren't targeted at specific classes, and more at playstyles.

Domination wasn't "Assassins", it was "snowballing". Which fits Assassins, but also Ganking Junglers, lane bullies and other early game champs.
Sorcery wasn't "Mages", it was "spellcasting and resources manipulation". Which fits Mages, but pretty much any champ that don't use exclusively their auto-attacks.

Sorcery will still be used as a Secondary by tons of champs. As a Primary, maybe a bit less, especially with the new keystone Hail of Blades also being introduced in Domination at the same time. But saying it will be underused is in my humble opinion, a stretch.

But maybe you're right and it will actually be underused. And even then, so what? What's important is whether each champ has attractive Runes and interesting choices in the Rune system. If Mages don't use Sorcery but still have good Runes, that's not a problem.

Yeah, again, we're probably just going to agree to disagree on this XD

I *do* think dom/insp is a less attractive option for mages, and I think their class will be hurt by eliminating the tree. You're making good points, but they don't change my mind. I think mages deserve to feel good about going into the sorcery tree, and this change has a negative impact on that (in my opinion).

We'll have to see if it's underused or not. I could be 100% wrong, and if the change goes through, I hope I am.

i think the idea for moving ultimate hat to D4 was to have it compete with the other hunter runes. and i think it was a good decision from a balance perspective because it's kindof ...boring to have something stack just by using your ulti. and the fact that ulti hat had 5 stacks made it a very good candidate for the hunter row. 

but i do agree with you on that nimbus cloak fits better in domination. i think they should have it switch spots with taste of blood because no one is really going to be taking a sustain rune like taste of blood when you need something like overheal to make it viable, and to also have it compete 2 very valuable offensive runes.

I definitely see that. I think some kind of re-tooling of ulti hat would have been my preferred solution, though. 

I don't know that I would have cared if ulti hat *started* in domination. It just feels disruptive to move it when mage players have gotten used to it. I don't see the tangible benefit to the game that justifies it.
YES times 100. I wasnâ€™t super excited because he can just run people down with his ult and they can take get away so easily like before.

Hey all,

Nimbus Cloak/Ultimate Hunter are still bound for 8.11 patch and will be returning to the PBE for further testing soon.

Great, can you change the caption on Sorcery from 'Unleash Destruction' to 'Run Really Fast' while you're at it? 

There's far too many runes in this tree that increase MS already, another is completely unneeded. With this rune it's entirely possible to just take effects that boost MS for the whole tree, does that seem like what Sorcery should be about to anyone?

> [{quoted}](name=LankPants,realm=OCE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EtX5N9zL,comment-id=00090001,timestamp=2018-05-16T23:31:30.714+0000)
>
> Great, can you change the caption on Sorcery from 'Unleash Destruction' to 'Run Really Fast' while you're at it? 
> 
> There's far too many runes in this tree that increase MS already, another is completely unneeded. With this rune it's entirely possible to just take effects that boost MS for the whole tree, does that seem like what Sorcery should be about to anyone?

You don't have to take them all if you don't want, but if you can make it work, more power to you!

This does not even begin to address the argument. The point LankPants made is that there are too many runes in Sorcery that focus on additional movement speed, which is a thematic mismatch with the intended purpose of the tree, and which crowds out space that could have been given to actual spell-focused effects. With the removal of Ultimate Hat and the addition of yet another movement speed rune, this problem will only worsen, as there will soon be 4 runes out of 12 in the tree, including one keystone, that focus on granting movespeed. Do you not see a problem with one-third of a spell-oriented tree being all about moving quicker?

I get that it must be exciting as a designer to implement the option to go into Sorcery and stack nothing but movement-based runes, but that is simply not what players in general want or expect with the tree. Considering how disappointing Sorcery has been overall, it is sad to see it taken in what is largely being regarded as exactly the wrong direction. Why not simply move these movement-based effects to Domination, and give Sorcery some of its more caster-oriented effects instead? There are several Domination runes that could be a good fit to Sorcery, namely Ingenious Hunter, Cheap Shot, Electrocute, pretty much all of the Tracking/ward-based runes, and obviously Ultimate Hunter once it gets added.

In general, it feels like Domination got a lot of the cool effects that Sorcery could've used, and I think switching at least some of these options around would establish a clearer difference between the trees, as both currently offer different ways of dealing more damage and moving faster within each tree. Would it not make more sense to have Domination focus on offering different ways of enhancing one's movement, and have Sorcery augment one's casting?

Just take goddamn Domination then. If you want burst - you go domination. Dom isn't an assassin only tree - it's a "Burst tree" while Sorcery is directed towards granding you ways to unleash your already built in burst or to shift your burst only gameplay into something else. There are a bunch of mages who struggle to really lay out their burst because they can't catch up to their enemies. That's a good tree for them!
There are other, who deal in a lot of dots and sustained damage... Aery is there to cover that! You cal also take absolute focus and scorch. Bam. You got a poker tree.
"Unleash destruction" doesn't mean "burst". It means adding ways for said destruction to be unleashed.

> [{quoted}](name=Vartius,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EtX5N9zL,comment-id=00090001000000000000,timestamp=2018-05-17T10:36:06.927+0000)
>
> "Unleash destruction" doesn't mean "burst". It means adding ways for said destruction to be unleashed.

"Unleash destruction" does not mean "move really fast" either, and it's pretty clear that Sorcery was intended to be the mage tree, while Domination was designed as the assassin tree. Neither tree may be exclusively designed for one or the other, but those are the classes they are primarily intended to cater to. If Sorcery is intended to be the spell-based tree, yet I have to go to Domination to enhance my spell-based damage, then there has been a failure in organizing and labeling those trees. If a mage really struggles with mobility (who, exactly?), it would make sense to take Domination as a secondary tree to cover those weaknesses, rather than to turn Sorcery into a movespeed rune set.

Why would assassins want to move fast though? Like really. Most have ample ways to go in and out of fights (May it be for the better or for worse). Aside from that:
1. Who gives a shit what were the trees supposedly designed for? What matters is what they do - in Domination you have burst, in Resolve you have tankyness, in Inspiration you have some random shit lol, in sorcery you have: Mobility, Poking tools, other things useful in mid lane (Nullyfying orb against other mages).
A lot of mages use electrocute already: Ahri, Anivia, Syndra and Lissandra are just some examples. Most of AP assassins use the dom tree as well: LeBlanc, Fizz, Akali, etc.
Why wouldn't they go Domination? Because it's "the assassin tree"? Bullshit. They take what works. And Domination works for Burst Mages and AP assassins.
Sorcery, on the other hand, works for mages who deal more in pokes.
Ziggs, Vel'koz and Xerath for example use Arcane Comet. Why?
Because they poke enemies from afar using their abilities, but said spells have enough cooldown for them not to use aery.
Aery is for mages like Karthus or Orianna, who are either encouraged to do basic attack or have a CD low enough on an easy to hit spell.
Mordekaiser uses Aery, but he is switching to Phase now that it got buffed.
Malzahar uses Aery because he has tons of dots and other abilities that make aery attack each time it's ready.
And for those mages Aery will do a ton of damage over the course of the game.
2. Mages who want to move quick? Aurelion Sol and Cassiopeia are good examples. I can see Viktor using Nimbus Cloak with the way his ulti works. Also he was already taking Fleet Footwork, so that's that. Mordekaiser will most likely take the entire movement speed route. I don't play that many mages so I don't know.
3. They aren't turning sorcery into a movement speed set. Yes. A lot of runes give movement speed in that tree... So? It doesn't mean they are turning it into a mov speed tree. They are making it possible for mages who WANT movement speed to make a tree for that purpose. Meanwhile the other mages who want to use sorcery (poke and sustained damage dealers) still have what they need.

Ultimate hat by all means belonged far better in domination.
Dom is for bursts. Ultis are usually a big part of bursts. Making the window between those bursts shorter IS the way to go for a tree that caters to burst.
Meanwhile if you look at sorcery NOTHING there made sense with ulti cooldown lowered. Aery and Comet are used by poke mages and don't really interact overly well with most ultimates.
You have 10% cooldown on all spells instead. It also makes sense. If you are a poke mage or sustained damage dealer you will want to make the window between individual spells shorter.
If you want to burst opponents... you don't need cooldown on all spells to be lower. You will most likely use a spell once in a combo.

What's not fine is when they do so for reasons that are meant to be core to another tree. Therefore, when people go into the caster tree because they want to move faster, and go into the assassin tree because they want to augment their casting, something's wrong with the way those trees have been designed.

Its keystones are notorious for being among the worst out of all the rune trees, and its only saving grace was that some of its lesser runes worked well on casters. Ultimate Hat was the best example of this, as it was legitimately useful on most casters, so to see it removed simply has the entire tree become less interesting and consistent overall.

CDR is therefore incredibly powerful on any kind of caster, no matter how bursty, because it gives them faster windows of damage and recovery, which can make all the difference in fights.
